post.content:
2️⃣0️⃣ Here's the 20th post highlighting key new features of the upcoming v258 release of systemd. #systemd258

Kernel files systems learn new mount options all the time. Often one wants to enable an option in a graceful fashion: if the kernel is new enough and provides the mount option, use it – and if not, then not.

We ran into this problem when we enabled quota support on tmpfs (see other story in this series): only new kernels support it, old kernels do not.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

replies.content:
While user quota on /tmp/ is certainly an important feature to lock down what bad code can do with this highly problematic directory, one can argue that not enabling it is also OK, after all this is how this worked for the last decades. Hence, being able to use the new knob, but gracefully suppress it on old kernels makes a lot of sense.

With the new x-systemd.graceful-option= pseudo mount option we implement a way out for this, in v258. As argument it takes a mount option string.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content:
If the kernel supports that mount option it is added as regular mount option to the option string, but if it does not, its is suppressed. The tmp.mount unit hence uses this option setting now:

Options=mode=1777,strictatime,nosuid,nodev,size=50%%,nr_inodes=1m,x-systemd.graceful-option=usrquota

This works for any kernel mount option, not just the quota options. However, it will *not* work for userspace mount options, that some file systems support, in particular fuse ones.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content: (If you try anyway to use userspace mount options with this new pseudo-option then the mount option will be assumed to be unsupported, i.e. the setting has no effect).

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content: @agowa338 Two reasons: this implies per-user mount namespaces, so that /tmp/ can be over-mounted. This also means that we need to disable mount propagation from user namespace to host somewhat (because otherwise the per-user tmpfs would propagate too, which is after all explicitly not what we want). But that also means many mounts can no longer established from user context, because noone else would see them. Which might be OK in some scenarios, but is not universally accepted as OK.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content: @agowa338 And then there's the other thing: applications use /tmp/ not just for storing temporary stuff, but also as a way to communicate, and that breaks when you disassociate /tmp/ for each user. For example X11 puts its sockets there, mysql used to, as well. It's all pretty awful, but we probably cannot ignore that this is done.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content: @agowa338 PrivateTmp= as service setting works because it is opt-in, and per service, so that one can decide for each service individually if mount prop being off is a problem, or if they use /tmp/ for communication. But doing this blanket for all user process is likely going to piss off a lot of people.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content: @agowa338 I am not saying we shouldn't do this eventually, but it's certainly not a clear-cut "let's just do this" thing.

fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

@pid_eins Why not just mount a process specific /tmp for security relevant usages?
Aka "PrivateTmp=True"?

Isn't that enough to lock it down?

@pid_eins
Hmm, thinking about this, would this also fix the poor performance of /tmp or does the kernel consider all tmpfs mounts as one internally?

Referring to the strange behavior of tmpfs being sometimes slower than nvmes despite being within ram. (Someone said within their writeup that this may be because of being single threaded within kernel space).

Sounds at least like it would have the side effect of working around this issue.

Maybe trying it later on a test machine...

all_descendants.content:
@pid_eins True, but is this relevant to the scenarios needing this level of security?
I mean I don't think they have that many dynamic mounts at runtime and I'd also expect them to properly scope which applications need to share such things by putting them into the same mount namespace using "JoinsNamespaceOf=" and such.

And others sooner or later will run into wird issues as nobody reads the docs and expects things to work like they did 30 years ago and is surprised when they don't.
